Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is broadly directed towards geometry that is expected to underlie various
duality phenomena in mathematics (Langlands program) and physics (Gauge Theory).
One goal is to reconstruct Loop Grassmannians and Mirkovic-Vilonen cycles from the
point of view of Statistical Mechanics, and apply this to constructing two dimensional
loop Grassmannians. Another project is a to establish Langlands duality for categories
of equivariant coherent sheaves on affine Steinberg varieties. A more technical project
is a geometric clarification of the Feigin-Frenkel description of the critical center Finally,
the projects on Quantum Field Theory are on reformulating Costello?s mathematical
formulation of perturbative QFT in terms of flows and a speculation on the relation of
QFT to Grothendiecks function-sheaf dictionary. The most ambitious project attempts
to create geometric for the arithmetic case of Number Theory through a 'stochastic set
theory'.

The project aims towards relating and unifying developments in mathematics and theo-
retical particle physics. The mathematical origin of these developments is the so called
Langlands program which is the modern view on a classical discipline of Number Theory. In time this program incorporated a number of central disciplines of mathematics, starting with Representation Theory, Algebraic Geometry and currently the Homotopy Theory. The relation to physics is a part of the current melting of barriers between mathematics and physics which arose in a period when the two subjects developed separately. The central impact on mathematics in the last quarter century was the import of the ideas from Quantum Field Theory (in particular String Theory), which is the part of physics that studies elementary particles. The proposed work attempts to work in both directions by applying ideas from physics to mathematics and mathematical constructions to physics. It also aims towards deeper understanding of the relation between Quantum Field Theory and Number Theory. The proposal also contains more standard topics within Representation Theory and Langlands Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The so called “Langlands program” and its outgrowth the “Geometric Representation
Theory” are central areas of contemporary mathematics which serve as a bridge between
the traditional mathematical disciplines of Number Theory, Algebraic Geometry, Representation Theory and the key developments in particle physics such as Quantum Field
Theory and String Theory.

The basis and the origin of the Langlands program is the so called “Class Field Theory”
which is the central body of knowledge in Number Theory. It resolves the main problems
of Number Theory in the case when the symmetries are simple (“‘the symmetry group
is commutative”). Langlands has proposed a web of conjectures that should extend the
results of Class Field Theory to the case of arbitrary symmetries. These have so far only
been formulated for objects of dimension one.

At this time the understanding of the Langlands program is rarely direct. The Langlands
conjectures predict the coincidence of some very rich and important data in two seemingly
unrelated settings. The current approach is mostly that for each class of phenomena one
calculates in impressive detail the data in the two settings and they always happen to
match as predicted.


Motivated by this lack of direct understanding my recent work is an attempt to reorganize
the Class Field Theory and the Langlands program so that one has a better chance of
seeing the nature of the relation that are predicted by the program. As a criterion of the
next level of clarity that I would like to achieve I have taken the principle that I should
be able to formulate the Langlands program in arbitrary dimension.

The work in this grant period falls into four categories, the first two deal with the special
case of Class Field Theory and the last two with the general Langlands program.
In Class Field Theory I have organized the present knowledge in the 1 dimensional case
according to a setting (a “Grothendieck topology”) that is (implicitly) used.

A. Zariski setting. In this case the results are most satisfactory. I have found a framework to treat the local and global theory uniformly and to extend the Class Field Theory
to arbitrary dimension. This involves a new version of one of central achievements of
Algebraic Geometry the motivic cohomology (and its Poincare duality).

B. Etale setting. This case is more complicated and so far I have still been working in
the traditional one dimensional setting. I expect that once a transparent formulation and
a proof of the central result of etale Class Field Theory (the class formation theorem)
is achieved, the higher dimensional case will be fairly clear. My current formulation is
“almost satisfactory”. To understand it better I am developing a new example of Class
Field Theory. This “de Rham” Class Field Theory is a reformulation of linear differential
equations on curves as a Class Field Theory.

C. Loop Grassmannians via local spaces. The loop Grassmannians are a key object
in the Langlands program. I have developed a new tool, the theory of “local spaces”,
and used it to reconstruct the loop Grassmannians in a way which makes the general
Langlands program closer to the special (and best understood) case of of the Class Field
Theory. At the same time one obtains a rich supply of new spaces that behave alike the
loop Grassmannians (the loop Grassmannians of quadratic forms and posets).

D. Loop Grassmannians for classifying pairs. The goal of this development is to
treat the relevant geometry of loop Grassmannians in a uniform and efficient way. To any
pair of spaces one associates generalized loop Grassmannian. Then the relevant subspaces
of loop Grassmannians (i.e., the ones that have traditionally been studied), are seen to
be themselves the loop Grassmannians in this new sense. In particular, this means that
these relevant subspaces which are usually infinite dimensional are now encoded into pairs
of finite dimensional spaces. This reduces computations with infinite dimensional spaces
to much simpler computations in finite dimension.

 

Due to the relation of the Langlands program to various areas, the project is expected
to eventually impact several major fields of mathematics and particle physics. For instance, the relation of the Geometric Langlands Program to the Gauge Theory ( a part of
Quantum Field Theory) leads to a hope that I will be (eventually) able to offer a tool to
construct the so called “theory X”, the conformal gauge theory in six dimensions which
is expected to unify known Quantum Field theories in lower dimensions.

 

I am training my PhD student Zhijie Dong in the theory of loop Grassmannians, based on
one of the developments in this project (the extension of the theory of loop Grassmannians
to classifying pairs).

I am also working with two postdoctoral appointees at U. of Massachusetts, Yaping Yang
and Gufang Zhao, based on another development in this project (a reconstruction and
a generalization of loop Grassmannians in the new framework of local spaces). They
have already produced significant results (a quantization of local spaces and a proof of
a version of the Kamnitzer-Knutson-Mirkovi ?c conjecture that relates quivers and loop
Grassmannians).
